head.title: Hypothesis Testing for the Population Proportion p (4 of 13)

body.p: Consider the population of part-time college students. Suppose that 60% of this population is female.

Here is the sampling distribution for the proportion of females in random samples of n students. The standard deviation is approximately 0.10. Lines indicate a distance of 1 and 2 standard deviations above and below the mean.

image.alt: A normal curve which is centered at a mean of 0.6 . The first standard deviation lines are at 0.5 and 0.7, and the second deviation lines are at 0.4 and 0.8 .

body.p: In this series of problems we will investigate how the sample size impacts the test statistic. Letâ€™s return to the context of example 3. The population is U.S. adults and we are investigating whether the proportion supporting the death penalty is still 0.64 (as it was in 2003).
Here is the sampling distribution for the proportion of supporters in random samples of 25 adults. The standard deviation is approximately 0.10.

image.alt: A normal curve which is centered at about 0.64 .

body.p: If we increase the sample size to 100, the standard deviation decreases to approximately 0.05, as shown.

image.alt: A normal curve which is also centered at about 0.64, but is much narrower with a lower standard deviation than in the previous image
